subject: Multiple sources have suggested parties are hoping to move to a possible 2200EST vote and scrap the 0100EST vote to end debate on 3-week continuing resolution, according to Twitter sources - Unconfirmed
China is to announce new PPP projects with value of USD 330bln
Sources state that meeting between Senators McConnell and Schumer has not yet led to an agreement on 3 week continuing resolution, according to CNN
PRE-MARKET JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Kawasaki Heavy (7012 JT) is expected to win a large order for subway cars from New York City
content:
JAPAN

Fujitsu (6702 JT)
- Co. is planning a USD 50bln investment to develop technology related to quantum computing by FY20. (Newswires)

Kawasaki Heavy (7012 JT)
- Co. is expected to win a large order for subway cars from New York City. (Newswires)

Lawson (2651 JT)
- Co. launches service to provide key storage for short-term vacation rentals with Canadian firm. (Newswires)

Nippon Paint (4612 JT)
- Co. largest shareholder Singapore Wuthelam Group is said to seek majority control of board. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT)
- Co. aims to create a global ride-hailing alliance after recent acquisition of Uber stake. (Newswires)

Toshiba (6502 JT)
- Co. reportedly considers IPO for chip business incase sale to Bain Capital doesn't receive regulatory approval. (FT)
- S&P raised rating 2 notches from CCC- to CCC+; Outlook Watch Positive. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Daewoo E&C (047040 KS)
- Hoban and Elion were said to have submitted final bids for stake in the Co. on Friday. (Yonhap)

Other News
- South Korea is reportedly seeking to broker discussions between US and North Korea. (Nikkei)
- South Korea’s financial regulator said it will tighten capital rules on high-risk household lending. (Yonhap)

Data Recap
- South Korean PPI (Dec) M/M 0.1% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)
- South Korean PPI (Dec) Y/Y 2.3% (Prev. 3.1%)
- South Korean Jan 1st-20th exports rose 9.2% Y/Y (Prev. 16.4%), while Imports rose 14.1% Y/Y (Prev. 19.5%).  (Newswires)

subject: US Senator Thune says hopeful of vote Sunday night to reopen government with a 3-week stop gap funding bill
Nigeria Central Bank says benchmark rate will be maintained at 14.00%, adds that January 22nd-23rd rate meeting will not be held
Toshiba (6502 JT) reportedly considers IPO for chip business incase sale to Bain Capital doesn't receive regulatory approval, according to reports in FT
US Senator Cornyn says thinks government will remain on shutdown for Monday
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN STOCK NEWS: National Australia Bank (NAB AT) is mulling potential IPO of its funds management, superannuation and financial advisory business
content:
Australian Pharma (API AT)
- Co. guides H1 net likely fell 9% to AUD 26.5mln vs. Exp. AUD 31mln, Co. signs heads of agreement with Auscann on distribution. (Newswires)

Bank of Queensland (BOQ AT)
- Co. hires several banks for a bond offering. (Newswires)

Charter Hall (CHC AT)
- Co. may offload 50% stake in Commercial & Industrial Property. (The Australian)

Domain Holdings (DHG AT)
- Co. CEO is to resign. (Newswires)
- Co. guides H1 digital revenue growth of 22% Y/Y. (Newswires)

National Australia Bank (NAB AT)
- Co. is mulling potential IPO of its funds management, superannuation and financial advisory business. (AFR)

Quintis (QIN AT)
- Co. has been placed into voluntary administration. (Newswires)

Basic Materials / Energy
- Spot gold rose 0.4%.
- WTI crude fell 0.6%.
- Iron ore rose 2.5%.

subject: US Senate is reportedly on course to conduct a procedural vote at 0100EST to fund government through February 8th
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION:
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS: US government shuts down; Germany's SPD voted for formal coalition talks with Merkel's conservatives
content:
ASIA-PAC

Seoul is said to broker talks between North Korea and the US. (Nikkei)

South Korean PPI (Dec) M/M 0.1% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Seoul is said to broker talks between North Korea and the US. (Nikkei)

South Korean PPI (Dec) M/M 0.1% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)
South Korean PPI (Dec) Y/Y 2.3% (Prev. 3.1%)


US

US government has gone into a shutdown after the Senate on Friday failed to secure a deal to fund government prior to the deadline, with only 50 Senators voting for the procedural motion which was 10 short of the 60 needed to advance the bill. (Newswires)

 

Senate is expected to vote after midnight or early hours of Monday to try pass a stop gap budget and re-open the government. (Newswires)


The White House stated that President Trump made several calls and spoke to a few Senators regarding the shutdown, while there were earlier reports of Trump blaming the shutdown on the Democrats and suggested for Republicans to invoke a ‘nuclear option’ to try pass a long-term bill instead of continuing resolutions. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES: SPX +0.44% at 2810, DJI +0.21% at 26071, NDX +0.35% at 6834.

Top performers:  Consumer Staples +1.11%, Consumer Discretionary 0.87%, Financials 0.68%

Bottom performers: Utilities -0.29%, Energy -0.10%, IT +0.16%


The S&P 500 printed another fresh intraday record highs, looking through the threat of a government shutdown. Consumer sectors lead the gains on expectations of lower tax bills, as well as a solid global economic backdrop. On the other end of the scale, the defensive utilities sector was lagging, with energy also lower.

TREASURIES: 10-Year T-Note futures settle 5+ ticks lower at 122-09

The curve steepened on Friday, with yields on 2s c.2bps higher on the day, while the longer end was higher by c.3bps. However, major spreads narrowed again, with 2s10s marginally flatter, while 2s30s and 5s30s flattened by 0.5bps and 0.8bps at settlement, respectively. 2s5s, however, widened slightly.

 

The 10-year yield rose to just shy of 2.65%, and was getting some attention given that it is now within the “Gundlach zone”, which he said would put pressure on stocks.

 

Some had suggested that yields have been rising this week – in spite of little progress in passing a bill to keep the government open – on the back of rising commodity prices generating some upside inflation pressures. However, analysts have noted that such a driver has historically delivered little in terms of a sustainable, long-term impact on inflation.

 

 

UK/EU

Germany’s SPD voted in favour (362 vs. 279) of formal coalition discussions with German Chancellor Merkel’s conservatives. There were also comments from SPD leader Schulz who said that coalition talks are going to be just as hard as the exploratory talks and that he hopes negotiations will start soon. (Newswires)

 

Fitch upgraded Spain to A-, outlook stable and affirmed Turkey at BB+, outlook stable. (Newswires)

 

S&P raised Greece sovereign rating one notch to B from B-, outlook positive and affirmed Czech Republic at 'AA-/A-1+' foreign currency and 'AA/A-1+' local rating, outlook stable. (Newswires)

 


FX

DXY red for the fifth straight week

The Dollar Index was flat on Friday, despite the looming threat of a government shutdown; the DXY finishes red for the fifth consecutive week, the longest losing run since May 2015. And despite widening rate differentials between USTs and JGBs, the JPY continues to strengthened against the greenback.

The EUR was also flat on Friday, with the single currency eyeing Sunday’s vote in Germany to see if the SPD will enter into a government coalition. Analysts generally see EUR downside in the event that it votes against it, since it would raise the prospect of either another election in Germany, or a minority government.

Sterling was negative on the day after the strong gains made this week, finishing US trade shy of the 1.39 handle. With Brexit developments quiet, and a generally reasonable run of economic data, the pound found demand this week against the currencies weighed down by political uncertainty (USD, EUR).

 

COMMODITIES

WTI futures settled 58 cents lower $63.37 per barrel; Brent futures settle 70 cents lower at $68.61 per barrel. Oil prices slipped by the most this week since October, despite hitting a three-year high in the week.

OPEC and Russia reaffirmed they will continue with oil-production cuts until year-end and indicated a willingness for cooperation beyond the date as Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih commented that there is consensus among producers to continue their cooperation beyond this year, while UAE’s Oil Minister Mazrouei said UAE wants a proposal for cooperation after 2018. (Newswires)

 

The IEA reported on Friday that US crude output is expected to rise above 10mln BPD – in line with what OPEC reported on Thursday. It also said that global stockpiles were tightening substantially on the back of the OPEC/non-OPEC deal to curb output. 

 

Elsewhere, weekly rig count data showed US driller cutting active rigs for the second straight week.

South Korean PPI (Dec) Y/Y 2.3% (Prev. 3.1%)
